PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

Note: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: FELIX PHIL VINCENT BELLIVEAU
2. Your address: ETHELTON, SASKATCHEWAN
3. Date: APRIL 7, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): MIDDLE EAST PUDNICO, YARMOUTH COUNTY, NOVA SCOTIA, CANADA
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: ZACHARIA BELLIVEAU, A SEA CAPTAIN
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March, 1902
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Butte City, Montana in 1898; Strathclair, Manitoba in 1900; Lac du Bonnet in 1901; Pine River, Man. in 1902.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 31 years.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? As a sailor going to Iceland I saw 3 men go overboard - I thought the life expectancy in that work wasn't high enough. As a miner in Montana for Marcus Daly, I knew two men were killed + 2 maimed in a makeshift cage (a barrel hoist), so I thought that was too dangerous, too.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through other people, I learned about farming in Strathclair, Man. (this was in 1898) when I quit the mine + hauled ice in 1901 when I went to the bush. I met a man and his brothers. The man I had met before in Nova Scotia. They had been working on farms in Carberry, Man. where the farmers were talking about the Carrot River Valley. They and I decided to file on homesteads in the Carrot River Valley.
1. Your full name: Felix Phil Vincent Belliveau

2. Your address: Middle East Picton, Yarmouth County, Nova Scotia, Canada

3. Date: April 7, 1952

4. Where were you born? Middle East Picton, Yarmouth County, Nova Scotia, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Zachariah Belliveau, a sea captain

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? March 1902

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible. Olette (P.H.), Montana, Jan 1899; Strathclair, Manitoba in 1900; Lac du Bonnet in 1901; Pine River, Man.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use if was a small child.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? As a sailor going to Ireland in that work wasn't high enough. As a miner in Montana for Marcus Daly, I knew two men were killed & maimed in a make-shift cage (barrel hoist), so I thought that was too dangerous out there.

10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it. Railroads or government information?

I learned about farming in Strathclair, Man. This was in 1898 when I quit the mine & hauled seed. In 1901 when I went to the bush I met a man and his brothers. The man I had met before in Nova Scotia. They had been working on farms in Carberry, Man. Where the farmers were talking about the Carrot River Valley. They and I decided to file on homesteads in the Carrot River Valley.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? All they said was "Don't be too long away." I didn't go back for 16 years.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? I travelled from N.S. to Montana with a friend who had a cousin in Butte City.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train from NS to Boston, Mass., then C.P.R. from Butte City to Butte City, train from Butte City to Manitoba. When I came from end of steel, Erwood to the homestead I walked with one companion to Melfort and the 20 miles more to the shack. No harbor as we had just got out of the post-house with Smallpox.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc. We had to sleep in hay or barns (because of Smallpox). People gave us food outside on a box. We cached our clothes 10 miles from destination, as we were getting exhausted. We climbed trees to see our objective, a light house five to seven miles closer than the other two in the country, after checking with a man on the trail.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? A 10x15 foot sod shack built by the man who had filed by proxy for us in 1901.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? It was called Fletts' Springs. SE ¼ Sec 2, Twp 44, Rge 21 W.2. Now it is Ethelton.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

no other place

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Before: Miner.
Hauling fire.

After: Farmhand.
Surveying.
Sold first grain off Homestead No Prince Albert in 1905.
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
I traveled from W.S. to Montana with a friend who had a cousin in Butte City.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
By train from Butte City to Edmonton, then by horse-drawn carriage to Edmonton.

14. How far was your journey?
The journey was approximately 500 miles.

15. What difficulties did you encounter during your journey?
We encountered many difficulties, including harsh weather conditions and difficult terrain.

16. What was the most memorable experience of your journey?
Meeting with Indians and experiencing their culture was the most memorable experience.

17. What did you do when you arrived at your destination?
We set up camp and built a shelter.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?
I worked as a miner and later as a farmer.

19. How long did you stay in Western Canada?
I stayed for several years.

20. What did you do after you left Western Canada?
I returned to my home country.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Once a year to sister
Once a month to girl I planned to marry.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Sarah Jane Le Blanc Nov. 14, 1906, Prince Albert

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

no.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

---

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

I had been around a lot, and I thought the summers here were the best I ever breathed in.

Once, in the winter hauling lumber from Tom Sander son's mill at BARRIER RIVER, my companions sleigh broke through the topsoil. I got the foot set in taking off them, etc., I hope he was coming home, and lost the next. So I limped. Then I sat a stone lid on the floor & accidently stepped on it with my bare good foot. After that I didn't limp as one foot was as sore as the other.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? by what means of travel?

Went to PRINCE ALBERT to buy and sell - 65 miles.
Went to house parties & neighbors - 6 miles.
Team of horses on sleigh or wagon.
Walked across to neighbors ½ mile for social evenings.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory that you would like to recount?

I had been around a lot and thought I'd never be able to survive here, but I'm glad I did. I'm Sander

Once at Barrier River, we camped alongside

Lake through the trip. Got the boat out in taking off from the lake. Got the boat going down, and back to

meat. So I clipped. Then I set up the bed on the floor

and took off on it with my feet on good feet.

After that I didn't limp on me feet as much as before.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

   Rail came to Ethelton in 1929 no more had to go to Kinistino.
   House shop in Melfort (20 miles) quite often did.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   1902-1905 March, June, September, December to P.A.
   1905-1914 once a week except in need of seed or harvesting.
   1914-1932 anything except in need of seed or harvesting.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   1902-1905 March, June, September, December.
   We ourselves never have except at our country store.
   2 families go 12 or 20 miles regularly since 1932.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

   Kitchen stove.
   Dried fruit.
   Clothes.
   Small fraction - 1/4

   Now buy bedding & work clothes by mail order.
   Buy less by mail than during depression and than in pioneer days.

   ETHELTON RURAL TELEPHONE COMPANY 1914?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Yes or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Was sure by 1906.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes.

One thought it too cold for wife's health. 1907

One sold his homestead and moved to coast in 1907, returned later.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No.

Some have left permanently in recent years for coast, especially those able to retire.

Village, P.R. station took name of ETHELTON, too.

FLETT'S SPRINGS - named after the FLETT family on whose land it is located became post office, church, & post office discontinued, church in decline, residents of that point now coming to ETHELTON. 41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

1. The railroad came through our community in 1929

2. We established a continuation room for high school in 1926. This graduated many students and is still in operation.

3. We formed a rural telephone company in

4. We got the district served by electric power in 1950-51.
